metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Common Mistakes
This chapter points out some common JavaScript mistakes.
content.html: This chapter points out some common JavaScript mistakes.

content.text: Accidentally Using the Assignment Operator
JavaScript programs may generate unexpected results if a programmer accidentally uses an assignment operator ( = ), instead of a comparison operator ( == ) in an if statement.
content.html: JavaScript programs may generate unexpected results if a programmer accidentally uses an assignment operator (=), instead of a comparison operator (==) in an if statement.

content.text: This if statement returns false (as expected) because x is not equal to 10:
content.html: This if statement returns false (as expected) because x is not equal to 10:

content.code_html:
let x = 0;
if (x == 10)

content.text: This if statement returns true (maybe not as expected), because 10 is true:
content.html: This if statement returns true (maybe not as expected), because 10 is true:

content.code_html:
let x = 0;
if (x = 10)

content.text: This if statement returns false (maybe not as expected), because 0 is false:
content.html: This if statement returns false (maybe not as expected), because 0 is false:

content.code_html:
let x = 0;
if (x = 0)

content.text: An assignment always returns the value of the assignment.
content.html: An assignment always returns the value of the assignment.

content.text: Expecting Loose Comparison
In regular comparison, data type does not matter. This if statement returns true:
content.html: In regular comparison, data type does not matter. This if statement returns true:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = "10";
if (x == y)

content.text: In strict comparison, data type does matter. This if statement returns false:
content.html: In strict comparison, data type does matter. This if statement returns false:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = "10";
if (x === y)

content.text: It is a common mistake to forget that switch statements use strict comparison:
content.html: It is a common mistake to forget that switch statements use strict comparison:

content.text: This case switch will display an alert:
content.html: This case switch will display an alert:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
switch(x) {
  case 10: alert("Hello");
}

content.text: This case switch will not display an alert:
content.html: This case switch will not display an alert:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
switch(x) {
  case "10": alert("Hello");
}

content.text: Confusing Addition & Concatenation
Addition is about adding numbers .
content.html: Addition is about adding numbers.

content.text: Concatenation is about adding strings .
content.html: Concatenation is about adding strings.

content.text: In JavaScript both operations use the same + operator.
content.html: In JavaScript both operations use the same + operator.

content.text: Because of this, adding a number as a number will produce a different result from adding a number as a string:
content.html: Because of this, adding a number as a number will produce a different result from adding a number as a string:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
x = 10 + 5;       // Now x is 15
let y = 10;
y += "5";        // Now y is "105"

content.text: When adding two variables, it can be difficult to anticipate the result:
content.html: When adding two variables, it can be difficult to anticipate the result:

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
let y = 5;
let z = x + y;     // Now z is 15

let x = 10;
let y = "5";
let z = x + y;     // Now z is "105"

content.text: Misunderstanding Floats
All numbers in JavaScript are stored as 64-bits Floating point numbers (Floats).
content.html: All numbers in JavaScript are stored as 64-bits Floating point numbers (Floats).

content.text: All programming languages, including JavaScript, have difficulties with precise floating point values:
content.html: All programming languages, including JavaScript, have difficulties with precise floating point values:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // the result in z will not be 0.3

syntax_highlighting.text: // the result in z will not be 0.3

content.code_html:
let x = 0.1;
let y = 0.2;
let z = x + y            // the result in z will not be 0.3

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // the result in z will not be 0.3

content.text: To solve the problem above, it helps to multiply and divide:
content.html: To solve the problem above, it helps to multiply and divide:

syntaxHighlighting.text: let z = (x * 10 + y * 10) / 10;       // z will be 0.3

content.code: let z = (x * 10 + y * 10) / 10;       // z will be 0.3

syntax_highlighting.text: let z = (x * 10 + y * 10) / 10;       // z will be 0.3

content.code_html: let z = (x * 10 + y * 10) / 10;       // z will be 0.3

syntax_highlighting_data.text: let z = (x * 10 + y * 10) / 10;       // z will be 0.3

content.text: Breaking a JavaScript String
JavaScript will allow you to break a statement into two lines:
content.html: JavaScript will allow you to break a statement into two lines:

content.code_html:
let x =
"Hello World!";

content.text: But, breaking a statement in the middle of a string will not work:
content.html: But, breaking a statement in the middle of a string will not work:

content.code_html:
let x = "Hello
World!";

content.text: You must use a "backslash" if you must break a statement in a string:
content.html: You must use a "backslash" if you must break a statement in a string:

content.code_html:
let x = "Hello \
World!";

content.text: Misplacing Semicolon
Because of a misplaced semicolon, this code block will execute regardless of the value of x:
content.html: Because of a misplaced semicolon, this code block will execute regardless of the value of x:

content.code_html:
if (x == 19);
{
  // code block 
}

content.text: Breaking a Return Statement
It is a default JavaScript behavior to close a statement automatically at the end of a line.
content.html: It is a default JavaScript behavior to close a statement automatically at the end of a line.

content.text: Because of this, these two examples will return the same result:
content.html: Because of this, these two examples will return the same result:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let power = 10    return a * power}

content.code:
function myFunction(a) {
let power = 10    return a * power}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let power = 10    return a * power}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a) {
  let power = 10 
  return a * power
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let power = 10    return a * power}

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let power = 10;  return a * power;}

content.code:
function myFunction(a) {
let power = 10;  return a * power;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let power = 10;  return a * power;}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a) {
  let power = 10;
  return a * power;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let power = 10;  return a * power;}

content.text: JavaScript will also allow you to break a statement into two lines.
content.html: JavaScript will also allow you to break a statement into two lines.

content.text: Because of this, example 3 will also return the same result:
content.html: Because of this, example 3 will also return the same result:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return a * power;}

content.code:
function myFunction(a) {
let  power = 10;    return a * power;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return a * power;}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a) {
  let
  power = 10; 
  return a * power;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return a * power;}

content.text: But, what will happen if you break the return statement in two lines like this:
content.html: But, what will happen if you break the return statement in two lines like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return  a * power;}

content.code:
function myFunction(a) {
let  power = 10;    return  a * power;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return  a * power;}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a) {
  let
  power = 10; 
  return
  a * power;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return  a * power;}

content.text: The function will return undefined !
content.html: The function will return undefined!

content.text: Why? Because JavaScript thought you meant:
content.html: Why? Because JavaScript thought you meant:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return;  a * power;}

content.code:
function myFunction(a) {
let  power = 10;    return;  a * power;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return;  a * power;}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a) {
  let
  power = 10; 
  return;
  a * power;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a) {
    let  power = 10;    return;  a * power;}

content.text: Explanation
If a statement is incomplete like:
content.html: If a statement is incomplete like:

content.code_html: let

content.text: JavaScript will try to complete the statement by reading the next line:
content.html: JavaScript will try to complete the statement by reading the next line:

content.code_html: power = 10;

content.text: But since this statement is complete:
content.html: But since this statement is complete:

content.code_html: return

content.text: JavaScript will automatically close it like this:
content.html: JavaScript will automatically close it like this:

content.code_html: return;

content.text: This happens because closing (ending) statements with semicolon is optional in JavaScript.
content.html: This happens because closing (ending) statements with semicolon is optional in JavaScript.

content.text: JavaScript will close the return statement at the end of the line, because it is a complete statement.
content.html: JavaScript will close the return statement at the end of the line, because it is a complete statement.

content.text: Never break a return statement.
content.html: Never break a return statement.

content.text: Accessing Arrays with Named Indexes
Many programming languages support arrays with named indexes.
content.html: Many programming languages support arrays with named indexes.

content.text: Arrays with named indexes are called associative arrays (or hashes).
content.html: Arrays with named indexes are called associative arrays (or hashes).

content.text: JavaScript does not support arrays with named indexes.
content.html: JavaScript does not support arrays with named indexes.

content.text: In JavaScript, arrays use numbered indexes :
content.html: In JavaScript, arrays use numbered indexes:

content.code_html:
const person = [];
person[0] = "John";
person[1] = "Doe";
person[2] = 46;
person.length;       // person.length will return 3
person[0];           // person[0] will return "John"

content.text: In JavaScript, objects use named indexes .
content.html: In JavaScript, objects use named indexes.

content.text: If you use a named index, when accessing an array, JavaScript will redefine the array to a standard object.
content.html: If you use a named index, when accessing an array, JavaScript will redefine the array to a standard object.

content.text: After the automatic redefinition, array methods and properties will produce undefined or incorrect results:
content.html: After the automatic redefinition, array methods and properties will produce undefined or incorrect results:

content.code_html:
const person = [];
person["firstName"] = "John";
person["lastName"] = "Doe";
person["age"] = 46;
person.length;      // person.length will return 0
person[0];          // person[0] will return undefined

content.text: Ending Definitions with a Comma
Trailing commas in object and array definition are legal in ECMAScript 5.
content.html: Trailing commas in object and array definition are legal in ECMAScript 5.

content.code_html: person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:46,}
points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10,];

content.text: WARNING !!
content.html: WARNING !!

content.text: Internet Explorer 8 will crash.
content.html: Internet Explorer 8 will crash.

content.text: JSON does not allow trailing commas.
content.html: JSON does not allow trailing commas.

content.code_html: person = {"firstName":"John", "lastName":"Doe", "age":46}
points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

content.text: Undefined is Not Null
JavaScript objects, variables, properties, and methods can be undefined .
content.html: JavaScript objects, variables, properties, and methods can be undefined.

content.text: In addition, empty JavaScript objects can have the value null .
content.html: In addition, empty JavaScript objects can have the value null.

content.text: This can make it a little bit difficult to test if an object is empty.
content.html: This can make it a little bit difficult to test if an object is empty.

content.text: You can test if an object exists by testing if the type is undefined :
content.html: You can test if an object exists by testing if the type is undefined:

content.code_html: if (typeof myObj === "undefined")

content.text: But you cannot test if an object is null , because this will throw an error if the object is undefined :
content.html: But you cannot test if an object is null, because this will throw an error if the object is undefined:

content.code_html: if (myObj === null)

content.text: To solve this problem, you must test if an object is not null , and not undefined .
content.html: To solve this problem, you must test if an object is not null, and not undefined.

content.text: But this can still throw an error:
content.html: But this can still throw an error:

content.code_html: if (myObj !== null && typeof myObj !== "undefined")

content.text: Because of this, you must test for not undefined before you can test for not null :
content.html: Because of this, you must test for not undefined before you can test for not null:

content.code_html: if (typeof myObj !== "undefined" && myObj !== null)
